ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Physical and dispersive optical characteristics of ZrON/Si thin-film system

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Centre of Advanced Materials, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Electronic Materials Research Group, School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Engineering Campus

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: To date, the complex evaluation of physical and dispersive optical characteristics of the ZrON/Si film system has yet been reported. Hence, ZrON thin films have been formed on Si(100) substrates through oxidation/nitridation of sputtered metallic Zr in N2O environment at 500, 700, and 900 ∘C. Physical properties of the deposited films have been characterized by X-ray diffractometry (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED), and spectroscopic ellipsometry (SE). It has been shown that ZrON/Si thin films without optical absorption can be prepared by oxidation/nitridation reaction in N2O environment at 700–900 ∘C.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Miniaturization of electronic devices based on semiconducting substrates such as Si, Ge, SiC, and GaN has urged drastic downscaling of the thickness of gate dielectrics and search for new dielectric materials with high dielectric constant in order to attain low leakage current [1–3]. Many high dielectric constant (k) oxides have been suggested and investigated nowadays and ZrO2-based compounds are considered as one of the most promising materials for near future generation nodes [1–10]. ZrO2 is widely used in modern technology owing to its exceptional chemical stability, high mechanical and thermal properties, high refractive index, and wide optical transparency range [1, 2, 11–15]. ZrO2 thin film oxide in amorphous and crystalline phases can be deposited by various deposition methods and physical and optical characteristics of the films depend strongly on the real defect structure, including oxygen vacancies. Recently, the interesting technology of formation of zirconium oxynitride by simultaneous thermal oxidation and nitridation of metallic Zr films in N2O gas flow at high temperature has been developed [16–18]. The interface layer formation with intermediate chemical composition was found in ZrON/Si and ZrON/4H-SiC systems by depth-profiling X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. As was shown, the interface layer in the ZrON/Si system contains a dominant part of nitrogen introduced by the oxidation/nitridation process [16]. To date, the complex evaluation of physical and dispersive optical characteristics of the ZrON/Si film system has yet been reported. Hence, in the present work, the complex evaluation of physical and dispersive optical characteristics of the ZrON/Si film system has been carried out to reveal the parameters of the interface layer in detail. In order to evaluate the mentioned characteristics, high-quality ZrON/Si films were grown onto n-type Si(100) substrates at various oxidation/nitridation temperatures.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: n-type Si(100) substrates (resistivity: 1–10 Ω cm) were cleaned by a standard Radio Corporation of America (RCA) cleaning method and treated with a diluted HF solution with ratio of 1 HF:50 H2O for 15 s to remove native oxide from the surface prior to metallic Zr sputtering. An Edwards Auto 500 radio frequency (RF) sputtering system was used to deposit an ultra-thin 5-nm metallic Zr film on the cleaned Si substrates using an Alfa Aesar metallic Zr target with purity of 99.5 %. The RF power, working pressure, inert Ar gas flow, and deposition rate were configured at 170 W, 1.2×10−7 Torr, 20 cm3/min, and 0.2 nm/s, respectively. The oxidation/nitridation of the Zr metal layer was performed after the deposition. The Zr/Si samples were placed into a horizontal tube furnace and heated from room temperature to a set of temperatures (500, 700, and 900 ∘C) in an Ar flow ambient; the heating rate was constant at 10 ∘C/min. Once the set temperature was reached, N2O gas was then purged in with a flow rate of 150 mL/min for 15 min to form the ZrON/Si layer. Then the samples were eventually taken out at room temperature after the furnace was cooled to room temperature in an Ar ambient.

The dispersive refractive index n(λ) and extinction coefficient k(λ) were determined by means of spectroscopic ellipsometry (SE). Ellipsometric angles Ψ and Δ were measured as a function of λ in the spectral range of λ∼250–1030 nm using an ELLIPS-1771 SA ellipsometer [19]. The instrumental spectral resolution was 2 nm; the recording time of the spectrum did not exceed 20 s. The SE measurements were produced at three angles of incidence of a light beam on the sample of 50∘, 60∘, and 70∘. The four-zone measurement method was used with subsequent averaging over all the four zones. The ellipsometric parameters Ψ and Δ are related to the complex Fresnel reflection coefficients by the equation 1
$$ \mathrm{tg}\,\varPsi\cdot \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\varDelta} = \frac{R_{\mathrm{p}}}{R_{\mathrm{s}}}, $$ where R p and R s are the coefficients for p- and s-polarized light waves. To calculate the dependences of the refractive index n(λ) and extinction coefficient k(λ) on the optical wavelength λ, the experimental data were processed using the two-layer model of (air)–(homogeneous isotropic ZrON layer)–(homogeneous isotropic interface layer)–(homogeneous isotropic Si substrate). The optical parameters of the interface film were taken as related to SiO2 oxide [20, 21]. Thus, over the whole spectral range, the spectral dependences of polarization angles were fitted for m points of the spectrum by minimization of the error function 2
$$ \sigma^{2} = \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i = 1}^{m} \bigl[ ( \varDelta_{\exp} - \varDelta_{\mathrm{calc}} )^{2} + ( \varPsi_{\exp} - \varPsi_{\mathrm{calc}} )^{2} \bigr], $$ where Δ calc, Ψ calc and Δ exp, Ψ exp are, respectively, the calculated and experimental ellipsometric angles and m is the number of points in the spectrum.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the XRD patterns of ZrON produced at different temperatures of 500–900 ∘C for 15 min. A very strong intensity of the diffraction peak at 69.0∘ (inset of the figure) is recorded in all investigated samples and the peak is matched with c-Si(400). In addition, a minor peak at the diffraction angle (2θ) of 33.1∘ is also detected and it is matched with c-Si(211), as confirmed by The International Conference for Diffraction Data (ICDD) card numbers 01-089-2749 and 01-072-1426, respectively.
Fig. 1
XRD patterns for oxidized/nitrided samples for 15 min at various oxidation/nitridation temperatures (500–900 ∘C)

After the simultaneous thermal oxidation and nitridation process, t-ZrO2(101) and t-ZrO2(002) are revealed at diffraction angles of 29.8∘ and 33.3∘ (ICDD: 00-024-1164), respectively, for all films (Fig. 1a–c). According to the ICDD file 00-024-1164, interplanar spacings of t-ZrO2(101) and t-ZrO2(002) are 0.2995 nm and 0.2635 nm, respectively. Therefore, from the XRD analysis, it is suggested that crystalline t-ZrO2 is formed and the result is supported by the measured interplanar spacing obtained from energy-filtered transmission electron microscope (EFTEM) images, as reported in Ref. [16]. Thus, it can be inferred that ZrO2 is embedded in an amorphous structure of the ZrON film. The RHEED observation reveals the amorphous state of the top-surface layer of the ZrON films. As an example, the RHEED pattern measured from the film prepared at 500 ∘C is shown in Fig. 2. So, it can be concluded that the t-ZrO2 grains appeared only in the ZrON bulk.
Fig. 2
RHEED pattern recorded from ZrON film prepared at 500 ∘C

FTIR analysis was carried out in order to further identify the chemical functional groups in the samples. Figure 3 displays the FTIR transmittance spectra (1200–400 cm−1) of ZrON films produced at different temperatures of 500–900 ∘C for 15 min. The Si–Si vibration-mode band, which originates from the Si substrate, is located at 610 cm−1 in all samples. A sample of as-sputtered Zr on Si does not show any detectable peak of Zr–Zr and/or Zr–Si (not shown). This is because those inorganic bonds are inactive in the mid-infrared region (4000–400 cm−1) [21, 22]. For the produced samples, transmittance bands of the Zr–O vibration mode are detected at around 440 and 580 cm−1 and it is associated with ZrO2 [23, 24], with intensity increasing as the temperature increases. Besides, a band at 1100 cm−1 is recorded in all investigated samples. This band is related to the Si–O bond in Zr–O–Si stretching vibration or in Si–O–N vibration [24–26]. These results are complementary with the conclusions based on the XRD analysis above and XPS analysis as reported in Ref. [16].
Fig. 3
FTIR transmittance spectra for oxidized/nitrided samples for 15 min at various oxidation/nitridation temperatures (500–900 ∘C)

The complex dielectric function obtained from the SE measurements of ZrON films over the photon energy range of E=1–5 eV in shown in Fig. 4. For comparison, the earlier measured dielectric functions of ZrO2/Si, TiON/Si, and HfON/Si films are also shown [27, 28]. The dielectric function can also be expressed in terms of n and k by 3
$$ \varepsilon(E) = \varepsilon_{1} (E) + \varepsilon_{2} (E) = (n + \mathrm{i}k)^{2}, $$ where E is the photon energy. It should be pointed that the TiON/Si, HfON/Si, and ZrO2/Si films were prepared by ion-beam sputtering in Ar/O2 and N2/O2 atmospheres, respectively [27, 28]. As was estimated with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), the O:N ratios in the TiON/Si and HfON/Si films were as low as 50:9 and 51:6 [28]. Comparatively, the O:N ratio in the ZrON/Si film shown in Fig. 4 is as high as ∼70:2 [16]. The high O:N ratio evidently appeared due to a relatively high oxygen concentration in the chamber during the oxidation/nitridation reaction in the Ar/N2O gas mixture.
Fig. 4
Dielectric functions of MO x N y (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) and ZrO2 films

It is seen from Fig. 4 that a practically zero imaginary part ε 2=0 is obtained over the range of E=1.1–5 eV in HfON and high-temperature ZrON films. This is defined by the absence of optical absorption over the photon energy range. Respectively, the similarity of ε 1(E) functions found in HfON and high-temperature ZrON films indicates similar refractive-index dispersions. The noticeable optical absorption in the low-temperature ZrON film at E>3.5 eV induces the increase of ε 2 at high photon energies. This reveals incomplete oxidation/nitridation of Zr metal at 500 ∘C. The higher ε 1 values in ZrO2 oxide are defined by the higher refractive index of this oxide. Commonly, the energy behavior of dielectric functions of ZrO2, ZrON, and HfON compounds is similar because the energy band gaps in amorphous ZrO2 and HfO2 oxides are E
g =5.5–6 eV and, as it seems, the low nitrogen component is not able to induce a drastic E
g decrease [2, 3, 29]. The specific behavior of the ε(E) function in TiON is evidently governed by interband transitions at E>3.5 eV because of the low value of E
g =3.0–3.5 eV [2, 3, 29]. Above this, it is well known that nitrogen incorporation into TiO2 oxides decreases the band gap [30–33].

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In conclusion, the complex evaluation of physical and dispersive optical characteristics of the ZrON/Si thin-film system produced by simultaneous thermal oxidation/nitridation of Zr metal in N2O ambient was successfully presented for the first time. From the physical analysis, it was identified that an amorphous ZrON film was formed with embedment of t-ZrO2 nanocrystals. Through the optical dispersive analysis, it was deduced that incomplete oxidation/nitridation of Zr metal takes place at 500 ∘C, with a noticeable optical absorption at photon energy E>3.5 eV. Hence, it has been shown that ZrON/Si thin films without optical absorption can be prepared by oxidation/nitridation reaction in N2O ambient at 700–900 ∘C. The physical and optical dispersive characteristics reported in this study may serve as key knowledge to understand the functional properties of ZrON/Si thin films to work as dielectrics in metal–oxide–semiconductor (MOS)-based devices and high-refractive-index transparent layers in optical structures.
